pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:2.1: The nuns’ rules and their analysis
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:3.1: The chapter on offenses entailing suspension
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:4.1: 3. The training rule on walking in uninhabited areas
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:5.1: At one time the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in the Jeta Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:5.2: At that time a nun who was a student of Bhaddā Kāpilānī had an argument with the nuns and then went to her relatives’ village.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:5.3: Because she had disappeared, Bhaddā Kāpilānī asked the nuns, “Where’s so-and-so? She’s not to be seen.”
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:5.5: “Venerable, she’s disappeared because she had an argument with the nuns.”
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:5.6: “My dears, her relatives live in such-and-such a village. Go there and look for her.”
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:5.8: The nuns went there, and when they saw her they said to her, “Venerable, why did you go alone? We hope you weren’t assaulted?”
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:6.1: The nuns of few desires complained and criticized her,
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:6.3: “How can a nun walk in an uninhabited area by herself?” …
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:6.4: “Is it true, monks, that a nun did this?”
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:6.7: How can a nun walk in an uninhabited area by herself?
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:6.8: This will not give rise to confidence in those without it …
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:6.9: And, monks, the nuns should recite this training rule thus:
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:7.1: ‘If a nun walks in an uninhabited area by herself, then that nun too has committed an immediate offense entailing sending away and suspension.’”
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:8.1: In this way the Master laid down this training rule for the nuns.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:9.1: On one occasion two nuns were traveling on the main road from Sāketa to Sāvatthī.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:9.2: On the way they had to cross a river,
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:9.3: and they approached a boatman and said, “Please take us across.”
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:9.5: “Venerables, I’m not able to take both of you across at once.”
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:9.6: And so they crossed individually, alone with the boatman.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:9.7: When he had crossed with the first nun, he raped her.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:9.8: And when he had returned to the first bank, he raped the other nun as well.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:9.9: Afterwards, when they were walking together, they asked each other,
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:9.12: And you, Venerable, were you assaulted?”
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:10.1: Then those nuns went to Sāvatthī and told the nuns there what had happened.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:10.2: The nuns of few desires complained and criticized them,
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:10.4: “How can a nun cross a river by herself?”
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:10.5: Then those nuns told the monks,
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:10.6: who in turn told the Master. …
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:10.7: “Is it true, monks, that a nun did this?”
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:10.10: How can a nun cross a river by herself?
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:10.11: This will not give rise to confidence in those without it …
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:10.12: And, monks, the nuns should recite this training rule thus:
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:11.1: ‘If a nun walks in an uninhabited area by herself or crosses a river by herself, then that nun too has committed an immediate offense entailing sending away and suspension.’”
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:12.1: In this way the Master laid down this training rule for the nuns.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:13.1: On one occasion a number of nuns were walking through the Kosalan country on their way to Sāvatthī, when one evening they arrived at a certain village.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:13.2: One of those nuns was beautiful and graceful, and a certain man fell in love with her as soon as he saw her.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:13.4: Then, as he was preparing sleeping places for those nuns, he prepared hers to one side.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:13.5: And that nun thought, “This man is obsessed with me. If I go there for the night, I’ll get into trouble.”
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:13.7: Then, without telling the nuns, she went to a certain family and slept there.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:13.8: Then, when night had arrived that man went searching for that nun, and as he did so he knocked against the other nuns.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:13.9: Because they could not see that nun, those nuns said, “No doubt she has left with a man.”
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:14.1: When the night was over that nun returned to the nuns, and they said to her, “Venerable, why did you leave with a man?”
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:14.4: “I didn’t leave with a man, Venerables.”
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:14.5: She then told the nuns what had happened.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:14.6: The nuns of few desires complained and criticized her,
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:14.8: “How can a nun spend the night apart by herself?” …
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:14.9: “Is it true, monks, that a nun did this?”
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:14.12: How can a nun spent the night apart by herself?
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:14.13: This will not give rise to confidence in those without it …
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:14.14: And, monks, the nuns should recite this training rule thus:
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:15.1: ‘If a nun walks in an uninhabited area by herself or crosses a river by herself or spends the night apart by herself, then that nun too has committed an immediate offense entailing sending away and suspension.’”
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:16.1: In this way the Master laid down this training rule for the nuns.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:17.1: On one occasion a number of nuns were walking on a main road through the Kosalan country on their way to Sāvatthī.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:17.2: One of the nuns, needing to defecate, stayed behind by herself, and then followed behind the others.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:17.3: People saw her and raped her.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:17.4: That nun then went to the other nuns, and they said to her, “Venerable, why did you stay behind by yourself? We hope you weren’t assaulted?”
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:18.1: The nuns of few desires complained and criticized her,
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:18.3: “How can a nun stay behind the group by herself?” …
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:18.4: “Is it true, monks, that a nun did this?”
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:18.7: How can a nun stay behind the group by herself?
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:18.8: This will not give rise to confidence in those without it …
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:18.9: And, monks, the nuns should recite this training rule thus:
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:19.1: ‘If a nun walks in an uninhabited area by herself or crosses a river by herself or spends the night apart by herself or stays behind a group by herself, then that nun too has committed an immediate offense entailing sending away and suspension.’”
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:20.4: … The nun who has been given the full ordination by both complete Orders through a legal procedure consisting of one motion and three announcements that is irreversible and fit to stand—this sort of nun is meant in this case.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:21.1: Walks in an uninhabited area by herself:
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:21.2: If she then crosses it with her second foot, she commits an offense entailing suspension.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:22.1: If she goes beyond the vicinity of an unenclosed village with her first foot, she commits a serious offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:22.2: If she then goes beyond with her second foot, she commits an offense entailing suspension.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:23.1: Or crosses a river by herself:
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:23.2: wherever, after covering the three circles, the sarong gets wet when the nun is crossing, this is called a “river.”
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:23.3: When she has crossed with the first foot, she commits a serious offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:23.4: When she has crossed with the second foot, she commits an offense entailing suspension.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:24.1: Or spends the night apart by herself:
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:24.2: if she is in the process of going beyond arm’s reach of her companion nun at dawn, she commits a serious offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:24.3: When she has gone beyond, she commits an offense entailing suspension.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:25.1: Or stays behind a group by herself:
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:25.2: if, in an uninhabited area, in the wilderness, she is in the process of going beyond eyesight or earshot of her companion nun, she commits a serious offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:25.3: When she has gone beyond, she commits an offense entailing suspension.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:26.2: this is said with reference to the preceding offenses.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:27.2: there is an offense as soon as the misconduct is committed, and no pressing is required.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:28.2: she is sent away from the Order.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:29.2: … Therefore, too, it is called an offense entailing suspension.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:30.2: if she is the first offender.
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3:31.1: The third offense entailing suspension is finished.
